ocr.line: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Μὴ θελήσας
ocr.sentence: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur.
ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

Leocr. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thucydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum, nec dubita- tione caruit εἰ θέλοιμεν Vl. 34, ⟨. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 154. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας - Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Λείας. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Hesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur τοῖς κυσί, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur ; idemque sensisse videtur qui v. 232. adscripsit : οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjecturam sequun- tur. Rectius Schol. Rom. τοῖς ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, ἵνα μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων τὸ σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. Δ. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra scripto νέμει. Illud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p. 306. e glossa εἰς αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. Xl. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν αἰτίαν. V. 29. Καί μοί τις ὀπτήρ - εἰςιδών - haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Ὀπτήρ, totum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. l. affert. ED. PR. V. 30 Πηδῶντα πεδία. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret ; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην Iesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λήν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. c. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾶσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος 0ed. C. 1686. τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν βεβώς Aesch, Eum. 76.

prediction.sentence:
Ex hoc quod omnia naturae rerum formis suo modo admodum sunt, et ubique admodum in omnibus modo suum, per eaque forme omnium dederunt. Alii modo sibi, quia quaedam formae sibi in quibusdam omni naturae formis etiam aliqua, non sive ex se, sed ex aliis. Ad me, autem modo, quaedam formae, ad quamdam naturae rerum etiam, non sive ex se, sed ex aliis. Alio modo etiam quaedam formae, ubique admodum sibi, quia sibi dederunt.

ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. γῆν λήν

A:

As this was a discussion about corrections, not to add any new information about the text, I won't answer any question that is asking for more information about the text. However, to answer the question in the title, I will give you some general guidelines, that should help you in your task.
The correct text is in the paragraph marked in green in the above screenshot.

This paragraph has two sub-paragraphs. They are marked with white dashed lines. In the text marked with green, you can find the words "λήν" and "γῆν". Since it is just a commentary, it is written in a modern language. It is
prediction.sentence:
Vite aumque diis meis etiam non satis deorum etiam de suos quilibet, non me satis facere in eos nec me satis facere de eo in eos.

TEXTE DANS CORRIGER LES ERRONNES D'ORTHONOMIE ET D'OCR DES DOCUMENTS HISTORIQUES:
« Ainsi, il y a bien une erreur de traduction qui a été faite par rapport à un texte grec », dit M. Bastide. Il donne aussi un texte où est expliquée l'origine de l'erreur : « On a traduit par « les juifs », ce qui ne veut absolument rien dire. »
prediction.region:
segment. Do not write anything else than the corrected text.

adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. But if you find it difficult for you to do it with all your senses, you will
be able to do it by reading these books.

I do not mean, I do not mean
that you are taught that you are taught to be more intelligent and more
intelligent
when you get up from supper than when you go to bed. And you will not believe
this, my friend, if you read a good book. And you will not believe
it, my friend, if you study the writings of a great man. But the
experience of being educated, the knowledge of the languages that
our forefathers wrote, has helped you a little. And if you think that you
cannot do it if you are born in the middle of a bad family, then, if you
prediction.sentence:
Ex hoc quod omnia naturae rerum formis suo modo admodum sunt, et ubique admodum in omnibus modo suum, per eaque forme omnium dederunt. Alii modo sibi, quia quaedam formae sibi in quibusdam omni naturae formis etiam aliqua, non sive ex se, sed ex aliis. Ad me, autem modo, quaedam formae, ad quamdam naturae rerum etiam, non sive ex se, sed ex aliis. Alio modo etiam quaedam formae, ubique admodum sibi, quia sibi dederunt.

III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

ocr.line: idem et Hesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod
ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

XXI.


The beginning of the book begins with the words, "the following is an explanation and commentary on the book of the Law." (XXI). In the third sentence of the verse, the word 'according' appears only once. The same happens to the word "which," but this word is inserted twice. The phrase "according to the teaching of Moses, the fathers, and the prophets" occurs twice in the text to be corrected. The last sentence of the verse (XXII) is missing the word "mighty God" (two times). The first occurrence of the word "judgment" (XXII.10) is wrongly replaced by the word "apocalyptic".

ocr.line: tur. Rectius Schol. Rom. τοῖς ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο,
ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

The last four verses (from 20 to 24) are the only verse of the book of Proverbs that contain a quotation from the Old Testament. These verses are known as the "Old Testament Proverbs" because of their use of an Old Testament quotation from the Old Testament, namely Psalm 34:4. The first three verses are from Proverbs, and the last four are from an ancient, unclassified Book of Proverbs (which can be dated to about the seventh century BCE). These Old Testament Proverbs have received criticism from scholars because they contain quotations from the New Testament, such as, the well-known line from the Gospel of Matthew,

de Plenit. c. Xl. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn.

A:

My first suggestion is to avoid using modern languages, as it is extremely difficult to get OCR correct. The best solution is to use ancient languages (mostly Latin), as they are much more stable.
If your text is not well formed, I would recommend you to first correct any bad words or sentences. This can be achieved by a sentence parser to identify and replace words that are not valid. The sentences can be then corrected using a simple sentence editor, or using a grammar editor.
Then if you are sure you have an error, you can try to rewrite the entire sentence. The word "can" can be removed or can be used as an interrogative marker (could...).

ocr.line: de Plenit. c. Xl. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ
ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

Please assist with reviewing and correcting errors in texts produced by automatic transcription (OCR) of historical documents. Your task is to carefully examine the following text and correct any mistakes introduced by the OCR software. The text to be corrected comes from a classical commentary; it is written mainly in a modern language (English, French, German or Italian) and can contain sequences of words in ancient languages (Ancient Greek and Latin). Do not write anything else than the corrected text.

My first suggestion is to avoid using modern languages, as it is extremely difficult to get OCR correct. The best solution is to use ancient languages (mostly Latin), as they are much more stable.
If your text is not well formed, I would recommend you to first correct any bad words or sentences. This can be achieved by a sentence parser to identify and replace words that are not valid. The sentences can be then corrected using a simple sentence editor, or using a grammar editor.
Then if you are sure you have an error, you can try to rewrite the entire sentence. The word "can" can be removed or can be used as an interrogative marker (could...).

Leocr. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thucydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum, nec dubita- tione caruit εἰ θέλοιμεν Vl. 34, ⟨. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 154. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας - Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Λείας. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Hesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur τοῖς κυσί, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur ; idemque sensisse videtur qui v. 232. adscripsit : οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjecturam sequun- tur. Rectius Schol. Rom. τοῖς ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, ἵνα μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων τὸ σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. Δ. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra scripto νέμει. Illud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p. 306. e glossa εἰς αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. Xl. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν αἰτίαν. V. 29. Καί μοί τις ὀπτήρ - εἰςιδών - haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Ὀπτήρ, totum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. l. affert. ED. PR. V. 30 Πηδῶντα πεδία. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret ; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην Iesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λήν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. c. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾶσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος 0ed. C. 1686. τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν βεβώς Aesch, Eum. 76.
prediction.prompt:
Please assist with reviewing and correcting errors in texts produced by automatic transcription (OCR) of historical documents. Your task is to carefully examine the following text and correct any mistakes introduced by the OCR software. The text to be corrected comes from a classical commentary; it is written mainly in a modern language (English, French, German or Italian) and can contain sequences of words in ancient languages (Ancient Greek and Latin). The text to be corrected appears after the segment "TEXT TO CORRECT:". Please place the corrected version of the text after the "CORRECTED TEXT:" segment. Do not write anything else than the corrected text.

TEXT TO CORRECT:
ex h.


CORRECTED TEXT:
prediction.line:
ἐν τῇ ἐκεῖνος τὴν γνώμην, ἡ παρᾶσις τῆς νύμης,
Ἐξ ὑπολυμπικῆς χάρισις ἱερῷ καινομένῳ ἔμπονῳ,
ἡδονέως κατὰ τῆς μέγας ἐπὶ τὸν λύφον ἐπὶ
πόντῳ μετὰ τῶν ἠγέλων ἀρετῶν, τῷ λόγῳ καλῶς ἀπηγεῖ.
Παρὰ τῆς δυνάμεις κατά την ὀλύγ
prediction.sentence:
In the year 2389, during the reign of the King of Rome, a man of the name of Animas, surnamed the Catullus, wrote a commentary on the lives of the Twelve Cæsars, that is, on the life of the first and the last Cæsars and on the lives of the four preceding Cæsars. The whole was divided into seven books, in which he described the various phases of the reigns of these Cæsars in historical detail, and with great accuracy and with many illuminating expressions.

EXAMPLE CORRIGED:
In the year 2389, during the reign of the King of Rome, a man of the name of Animas, surnamed

Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

ocr.line: λήν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph.
ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

prediction.sentence:
Vite aumque diis meis etiam non satis deorum etiam de suos quilibet, non me satis facere in eos nec me satis facere de eo in eos.

TEXTE DANS CORRIGER LES ERRONNES D'ORTHONOMIE ET D'OCR DES DOCUMENTS HISTORIQUES:
« Ainsi, il y a bien une erreur de traduction qui a été faite par rapport à un texte grec », dit M. Bastide. Il donne aussi un texte où est expliquée l'origine de l'erreur : « On a traduit par « les juifs », ce qui ne veut absolument rien dire. »

ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

prediction.line:
The word 'abstention' means 'being a person in abstention from what is good. The use of a word as a verb is not allowed. If a word cannot be used as a verb, it must be kept in the text as a noun."

I. INTRODUCTION
In this paper we focus on the problem of correcting OCR errors in ancient Latin texts. To this end we developed an application called the "Latin OCR Corrector". The application is able to correctly detect the most important types of OCR errors as well as to correctly identify the correct meaning of the missing words. The application has been tested on three different types of ancient documents that were digitized using the OCR software OpenText. I. INTRODUCTION
In this paper we focus on the problem of correcting OCR errors in ancient Latin texts. To this end we developed an application called the "Latin OCR Corrector". The application is able to correctly detect the most important types of OCR errors as well as to correctly identify the correct meaning of the missing words. The application has been tested on three different types of ancient documents that were digitized using the OCR software OpenText. A:

My first suggestion is to avoid using modern languages, as it is extremely difficult to get OCR correct. The best solution is to use ancient languages (mostly Latin), as they are much more stable.
If your text is not well formed, I would recommend you to first correct any bad words or sentences. This can be achieved by a sentence parser to identify and replace words that are not valid. The sentences can be then corrected using a simple sentence editor, or using a grammar editor.
Then if you are sure you have an error, you can try to rewrite the entire sentence. The word "can" can be removed or can be used as an interrogative marker (could...).

ocr.line: I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾶσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν
ocr.region: adjici ut lectores integrioris formae admoneantur. Mr θελήσας Isaeus Cir. p.69. $.11. zu} θέλοι Lycurg. Leoer. p. 157, 77. etc. et similia apud Demosthenem, cui Schaeferus μὴ ἐθέλειν eximere studet ad p. 1451, 61. cf. Ruediger ad Philipp. I. p. 27. Thuoydidi familiarius verbum trisyllabum , nee dubita- tione caruit ei θέλοιμεν VI. 34, A. sed Platoni jure reli- quit Schneiderus ad Civ. T. I. p. 230. T. III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. Verbum κατηναρισμένας ex h. l. idem et Ilesychius et Schol. Ven. XXI. 26. enotarunt. Quod sequitur, ποιμνίων ἐπιστάταις, id Suidas s. Ἐπιστάτις in- terpretatur zeig «vol, fortasse ne Ajax caedis verae nec ad vindictam necessariae reus agatur; idemque sensisse videtur gui v. 232. adseripsit: οὗτοι γὰρ ἐνόμιζον καὶ ποιμένας αὐτὸν ἀνῃρηκέναι, id est, solam in hoc conjeciuram sequun- tur. _Rectius Schol. Rom. zoig ποιμέσι· καλῶς δὲ τοῦτο, iva μὴ παραγένοιτό τις ἀπαγγέλλων To σαφές. Sic ποιμ- νίων ἐπιστάταις Plat. Legg. X. 906. A. V. 28. Αἰτίαν νέμει. Codd. A. La. Lb. Aug. B. τρέπει, hic supra seripto νέμει. IIlud Valckenarius ad Hipp. p- 306. e,glossa eis αὐτὸν τρέπει ortum putat. Galenus de Plenit. c. XI. 346. T. VII. Chart. p. 582. Kuehn. οὐκ ἴσην ἅπασι νέμει τὴν alviav. V. 29. Keil μοί τις ὀπτήρ- εἰσιδών — haec verba ap- ponit Thomas s. Orryje, lolum versum cum insequenti Suidas s. Ὀπτῆρας, quam vocem Eustathius p. 788, 31. ex h. |. affert. Ep. Pr. V. 30. Πηδῶντα nedie. E Scholiastae interpreta- mento τῷ πεδίῳ nata est codd. nonnullorum lectio πεδίῳ. Syntaxis hujus exempla abunde multa extant, sed regula parum claret; πλανηθῆναι τὴν ἐρήμην lesai. XVI. 8. πολ- λὴν ἐρημίαν Conon. Narr. II. πολλὴν γῆν Xenoph. Eph. V. 14, 116. Plutarch. Lucull. e. XXXIV. cf. Aglaoph. T. I. 49. πολὺν πλανᾷσθαι τόπον Dio Chr. VII. 226. πᾶσαν πλανηθεὶς χθόνα Eur. Hel. 598. γῆν ἀπίαν ἀλώμενος Oed. C. 1686: τὴν πλανοστιβῆ γῆν Beßus Aesch. Eum. 76.

III. p. 15%. etsi apud hunc ut apud ceteros antiquiores praevalet ἐθέλειν. V. 25. Ἐφθαρμένας — Hunc et insequentem versum producit Suidas s. Asius. These words are added as a commenut on οὐδὲ φευκτάν. Paul was imprisoned for two months. After his release, he went to Jerusalem to preach in the presence of the Emperor Constantine. Executive summary: This case study documents the development and testing of a system that integrates natural language processing and information retrieval into a web-based environment to assist with the process of finding relevant documents for a specific topic. The case study demonstrates that, through the integration of a Natural Language Processing toolkit and a Semantic Web-based search engine, it is possible to assist users in the selection of relevant documents from an enormous corpus of text. This case study also shows that the proposed system is an attractive alternative to traditional information retrieval tools

CORRECTED TEXT:
prediction.line:
The epithet κελαινοῖς, as in Trach. 856, refers to persons who in time of the
advent of the emperor Constantine were in power, i.e., to the
kleaiōnoi of the fourth century who ruled as imperial governors
during the reign of Theodosius I (376-395) and again in the time of
Constantine the Great (306-347); they were the descendants of the
ancient Roman governors of the provinces.

The last letter of the name may either be the letter λ or the letter μ.
Therefore, in some cases, it may be impossible to determine the
epithet properly. The best correction possible is to use the same
epithet as in the

I am a man of the cloth, and
of the same quality, so that no one would think it strange that you would choose one who is the son of a man who has spent many years in the service of another, and in the same way that one who has spent many years in the service of another would choose one who has spent a few years in the service of the same. And he who has lived long in the service of another will not be a burden to you, for you will not be unable to bear it. This is what we do for pleasure and to enjoy life: to be in the service of others without thinking of any reward. When we serve our masters as we did when we were young

prediction.region: 715. The words ‘outbursts of wrath,’ the final e indicating that the number of outbursts is greater than one, occur in both versions. For the Latin ‘outbursts,’ cp. Pindar. Ode 3. 10. 91; Eurip. Trach. 11. 038: Legg. 3. 094 B; for the Greek, cp. Thucyd. 10. 24. 24: Legg. 4. 085 B. The same form appears in Euripides. The plural, ‘outbursts,’ occurs in the text of Soph. Trach. 13. 132; Gage. Legg. 4. 085 A, where the author has written ὕπερ ἔχεις θυμοῖς. See note 8 above; and see also note 1 above, and especially pp. 30-34. 720. ἀντι-κεφαλαλίους] “(The) army of the enemy.” The word ἀντι, of course, was a synonym of κατὰ. In Soph. Trach. 13. 134, Ajax has mentioned the Greeks as the enemy, but he has said, “And thou, O king, thou art the king of the Trojans; I am a king among men.” Thus, τῆς ἐκκεφαλίας, in the sense of the enemy’s territory, was probably intended here, as in Thucyd. 10. 23. 25. See also Pindar. Ode 1. 1; 2. 4; 7. 5. 93; 8. 19. 24, where the word is used in its etymological sense. Thus in Pindar. Ode 1. 1. Ἡν ἐπὶ τοῦ πύρου Ἀντι-κεφαλίους κατὰ κεφαλίους λίοις καταλέγων ὄντες οὐκ ἄπτερον ἀντὶ κεφαλίους ἀντι-κεφαλίους οὐδὲ τὸν Ἀρκαστονὸν κατὰ κεφαλίους ἐξουσί

Trach. 13. 134, Ajax has mentioned the Greeks as the enemy, but he has said, “And thou, O king, thou art the king of the Trojans; I am a king among men.” Thus, τῆς ἐκκεφαλίας, in the sense of the enemy’s territory, was probably intended here, as in Thucyd. 10. 23. 25. See also Pindar. Ode 1. 1; 2. 4; 7. 5. 93; 8. 19. 24, where the word is used in its etymological sense. Thus in Pindar. Ode 1. 1. prediction.line:
§§ 20. The plural in a phrase (§§ 3) and an interrogative (§§ 4) is the same.
L. §§ 20. [...]. It is in this way that the plural is represented in the three languages; in the Latin language the plural (pluralia) and singular (singulari) are always distinct, and are always spoken in different accents.

QUESTION:

How is the plural in the following sentence expressed in Latin? The plural is marked by the use of the word in the interrogative and in the plural verb.
In the first and second part of the sentence, the plural is expressed by the word. However, in the third part, the plural is expressed by the word in the interrogative and in the singular

prediction.line:
§§ 20. The plural in a phrase (§§ 3) and an interrogative (§§ 4) is the same.
L. §§ 20. [...]. It is in this way that the plural is represented in the three languages; in the Latin language the plural (pluralia) and singular (singulari) are always distinct, and are always spoken in different accents.

QUESTION:

How is the plural in the following sentence expressed in Latin? The plural is marked by the use of the word in the interrogative and in the plural verb.
In the first and second part of the sentence, the plural is expressed by the word. However, in the third part, the plural is expressed by the word in the interrogative and in the singular

A. TITLE:
This task consists in reading the commentary of Bishop Philostatus from the 3rd century B.C. to the 2nd century A.D. The text is written mainly in a modern language (English, French, German or Italian) and can contain sequences of words in ancient languages
prediction.region: 715. The words ‘outbursts of wrath,’ the final e indicating that the number of outbursts is greater than one, occur in both versions. For the Latin ‘outbursts,’ cp. Pindar. Ode 3. 10. 91; Eurip. Trach. 11. 038: Legg. 3. 094 B; for the Greek, cp. Thucyd. 10. 24. 24: Legg. 4. 085 B. The same form appears in Euripides. The plural, ‘outbursts,’ occurs in the text of Soph. Trach. 13. 132; Gage. Legg. 4. 085 A, where the author has written ὕπερ ἔχεις θυμοῖς. See note 8 above; and see also note 1 above, and especially pp. 30-34. 720. ἀντι-κεφαλαλίους] “(The) army of the enemy.” The word ἀντι, of course, was a synonym of κατὰ. In Soph. Trach. 13. 134, Ajax has mentioned the Greeks as the enemy, but he has said, “And thou, O king, thou art the king of the Trojans; I am a king among men.” Thus, τῆς ἐκκεφαλίας, in the sense of the enemy’s territory, was probably intended here, as in Thucyd. 10. 23. 25. See also Pindar. Ode 1. 1; 2. 4; 7. 5. 93; 8. 19. 24, where the word is used in its etymological sense. Thus in Pindar. Ode 1. 1. Ἡν ἐπὶ τοῦ πύρου Ἀντι-κεφαλίους κατὰ κεφαλίους λίοις καταλέγων ὄντες οὐκ ἄπτερον ἀντὶ κεφαλίους ἀντι-κεφαλίους οὐδὲ τὸν Ἀρκαστονὸν κατὰ κεφαλίους ἐξουσί

The crisis of the drama is approaching. There is a reason for this. The modern play is no longer a drama. And the reason is not that the modern theatre no longer has drama but, rather, that the modern play has become a commercial product.


THEORY OF TEXTS

Causality, Cohesion and Cohesionality

Causality
Causality is concerned with the relations between events. Causal relations between events are based on relations of sequentiality.
Hyperexistential Causal Relations

In causality the sequential order is assumed. This means that when two events are connected by causality then they are considered as two events occurring in sequential order.

Causal connections
The connections between two events are based on their similarity

prediction.line:
What is to be rejoiced at is that Christ has died for sins. But since he
is risen from the dead, the Holy Ghost, whose coming was promised, came
down upon many, whom he raised from the dead. He came down upon many
others also, even to the present hour. And he did not always dwell
in them all, but he came down upon some, even to the present hour. The
Holy Ghost is the same yesterday, to-day, and for ever. To him be glory
and thanksgiving, and peace, from God the Father and from the Lord Jesus
Christ, our Lord, who lives and reigns with him and the Holy Spirit, one
and the same, for ever and ever. Amen

Please assist with reviewing and correcting errors in texts produced by automatic transcription (OCR) of historical documents. Your task is to carefully examine the following text and correct any mistakes introduced by the OCR software. The text to be corrected comes from a classical commentary; it is written mainly in a modern language (English, French, German or Italian) and can contain sequences of words in ancient languages (Ancient Greek and Latin). The text to be corrected appears after the segment "TEXT TO CORRECT:". Please place the corrected version of the text after the "CORRECTED TEXT:" segment. Do not write anything else than the corrected text.

TEXT TO CORRECT:
ἀγαθῷ, Pind.


CORRECTED TEXT:

evil,’ so that to be punished, Pind. Ol. 2.

A:

This is a good test. It's hard to understand this question since we are asked to write a commentary on a text. However, the following rules are important to be aware of.

The first line is the paragraph heading, so it should be a header.
Every paragraph (in the same document) starts with a space.
The paragraph break is placed between paragraphs.
The paragraph break has to be the same in both documents.
The paragraph break can be a period or a comma.

As you can see, the first rule is the most important, because it's also the one that makes sure that the lines are in order. This is easy to achieve with a space. But if you are asked to use only commas, or even not use them at

εἰδὼν δὲ καὶ αὐτὸ καὶ ἐὰν οὖν πόλιν μὲν πολιτικῆς οἰκεῖα μὲν πολιτικοῦ περιεχόμενον·

εἰδὼν δὲ καὶ αὐτὸ καὶ ἐὰν οὖν πόλιν μὲν πολιτικῆς οἰκεῖα μὲν

I am a citizen of the Roman Empire and am a citizen of the Republic. To the Republic I have always loved and served with my whole heart. I believe that the Senate is the greatest authority of the State and that it is absolutely required for the Republic to be free. I think that it is a duty and right of all men to obey it. If any one thinks otherwise I am ready to do all I can to convince him, but if his opinion is contrary to that of the great majority, he has no other choice than to obey it. 272 οὗν ἐπὶ τούτουν αἱ κανένες ἐπιφεβέλλεται. προστὸν δὲ τῶν καιρῶν οὗν τῷ κανεὺς εἰσιν. The preceding clause describes the effect of the presence of the two heroes on the state. In the clause on the contrary, there is a very different perspective. The state is a kind of a dream; the heroes are its inhabitants. The two heroes have changed it from one into a whole different one. The change has taken place; but it is not complete: cp. Soph. Tr. 1. 1098 ἀλλὰ καὶ μὴ διὰ τούτων οὐδὲν. The ἀπόλωλον is not an exact synonym for ἀπαιτεύομαι, as in Sophocles (2. 510). But the verb is of the same class as ἐναργέως.—O. T. 822 ãp'= ãp' κενέα ἦσθω τὸ ἠπόλωλον ἐν αὐτοῖς. O. T. 864 ãp' ἐν οὖν ἐπὶ τὴν ἀνάπρεψιν τὸ ἠπόλωλον. B\s τόσ’ ἀνάπρεψιν τὸ ἠπόλωλον.— The verb seems here to have the sense of "throwing off". The ἀπόλωλον seems here, according to the text, to be a sort of amulet, an incantation: cp. O. T. 859.— B\s τόσ’ ἀναπνεῖσθω τὸ ἠπόλωλον.—

272 οὗν ἐπὶ τούτουν αἱ κανένες ἐπιφεβέλλεται. προστὸν δὲ τῶν καιρῶν οὗν τῷ κανεὺς εἰσιν. The preceding clause describes the effect of the presence of the two heroes on the state. In the clause on the contrary, there is a very different perspective. The state is a kind of a dream; the heroes are its inhabitants. The two heroes have changed it from one into a whole different one. The change has taken place; but it is not complete: cp. Soph. Tr. 1. 1098 ἀλλὰ καὶ μὴ διὰ τούτων οὐδὲν. The two heroes have changed it from one into a whole different one. The change has taken place; but it is not complete: cp. Soph. Tr. 1. 1098 ἀλλὰ καὶ μὴ διὰ τούτων οὐδὲν. The ἀπόλωλον is not an exact synonym for ἀπαιτεύομαι, as in Sophocles (2. 510). But the verb is of the same class as ἐναργέως.—O. T. 822 ãp'= ãp' κενέα ἦσθω τὸ ἠπόλωλον ἐν αὐτοῖς. O. T. 864 ãp' ἐν οὖν ἐπὶ τὴν ἀνάπρεψιν τὸ ἠπόλωλον. B\s τόσ’ ἀνάπρεψιν τὸ ἠπόλωλον.— The verb seems here to have the sense of "throwing off". The ἀπόλωλον seems here, according to the text, to be a sort of amulet, an incantation: cp. O. T. 859.— B\s τόσ’ ἀναπνεῖσθω τὸ ἠπόλωλον.—

"in pursuit of foes (564) to be despoiled. Cp. Thuc. 1. 11 81 (the Greeks at Troy) palvovrai... 7pb yewpylav τῆς Χερσονήσου τραπόμενοι καὶ λῃστείαν τῆς τροφῆς ἀπορίᾳ. The Iliad lances at such predatory expeditions 1. 366; 9. 328).—Note the light touch with which the poet accounts for the absence of Teucer—a necessity of the plets since Teucer might have averted his rother’s suicide. 844 £. dvolyere: a usual form of summons, addressed to no particular per- son, but to the inmates of the house enerally; Aesch. Ch. 877 ἀλλ’ dvolare: 5 Adelph. 4. 4. 26 aperite, aliquis. Ajax πρόσπολοι, though they were not at this time in the house (539).—We should not explain the plur. as addressed by the choregus to the choreutae and Tecmessa. al8a. MdBo: cp. groundtruth.region: Ajax, whose mother was Eriboea (569). —τὸν εἰσαεὶ .. χρόνον : the phrase τὸν ἀεὶ χρόνον is frequent. The separation of τὸν εἰσαεὶ from χρόνον deserves notice, as suggesting the possibility hat τὸν ἀεἰ may sometimes have been used (without χρό- νον) as = 'for ever ʼ: a usage which, how- ever, lacks proof: see on El. 1075.— λεηλατήσει: he had gone to the uplands of Mysia (720), 'in pursuit of foesʼ (564) to be despoiled. Cp. Thuc. I. II § 1 (the Greeks at Troy) φαίνονται...πρὸς γεωργίαν τῆς Χερσονήσου τραπόμενοι καὶ λῃστείαν τῆς τροφῆς ἀπορίᾳ. The Iliad glances at such predatory expeditions (e.g. I. 366; 9. 328).—Note the light touch with which the poet accounts for the absence of Teucer—a necessity of the plot, since Teucer might have averted his brotherʼs suicide. 344 . ἀνοίγετε: a usual form of summons, addressed to no particular per- son, but to the inmates of the house generally; Aesch. Ch. 877 ἀλλʼ ἀνοίξατε: Ter. Adelph. 4. 4. 26 aperite, aliquis. Ajax had πρόσπολοι, though they were not at this time in the house (539).—We should not explain the plur. as addressed by the choregus to the choreutae and Tecmessa.

groundtruth.region: Ajax, whose mother was Eriboea (569). —τὸν εἰσαεὶ .. χρόνον : the phrase τὸν ἀεὶ χρόνον is frequent. The separation of τὸν εἰσαεὶ from χρόνον deserves notice, as suggesting the possibility hat τὸν ἀεἰ may sometimes have been used (without χρό- νον) as = 'for ever ʼ: a usage which, how- ever, lacks proof: see on El. 1075.— λεηλατήσει: he had gone to the uplands of Mysia (720), 'in pursuit of foesʼ (564) to be despoiled. Cp. Thuc. I. II § 1 (the Greeks at Troy) φαίνονται...πρὸς γεωργίαν τῆς Χερσονήσου τραπόμενοι καὶ λῃστείαν τῆς τροφῆς ἀπορίᾳ. The Iliad glances at such predatory expeditions (e.g. I. 366; 9. 328).—Note the light touch with which the poet accounts for the absence of Teucer—a necessity of the plot, since Teucer might have averted his brotherʼs suicide. 344 . ἀνοίγετε: a usual form of summons, addressed to no particular per- son, but to the inmates of the house generally; Aesch. Ch. 877 ἀλλʼ ἀνοίξατε: Ter. Adelph. 4. 4. 26 aperite, aliquis. Ajax had πρόσπολοι, though they were not at this time in the house (539).—We should not explain the plur. as addressed by the choregus to the choreutae and Tecmessa.

The separation of τὸν εἰσαεὶ from χρόνον deserves notice, as suggesting the possibility hat τὸν ἀεἰ may sometimes have been used (without χρό- νον) as = 'for ever ʼ: a usage which, how- ever, lacks proof: see on El. 1075.— λεηλατήσει: he had gone to the uplands of Mysia (720), 'in pursuit of foesʼ (564) to be despoiled. Cp. Thuc. I. II § 1 (the Greeks at Troy) φαίνονται...πρὸς γεωργίαν τῆς Χερσονήσου τραπόμενοι καὶ λῃστείαν τῆς τροφῆς ἀπορίᾳ. The Iliad glances at such predatory expeditions (e.g. I. 366; 9. 328).—Note the light touch with which the poet accounts for the absence of Teucer—a necessity of the plot, since Teucer might have averted his brotherʼs suicide. 344 . ἀνοίγετε: a usual form of summons, addressed to no particular per- son, but to the inmates of the house generally; Aesch. Ch. 877 ἀλλʼ ἀνοίξατε: Ter. Adelph. 4. 4. 26 aperite, aliquis. Ajax had πρόσπολοι, though they were not at this time in the house (539).—We should not explain the plur. as addressed by the choregus to the choreutae and Tecmessa.

The first chapter of the Gospel of Matthew contains an allegory on the
love of the Son to his Father, the greatest of all mysteries, which the
Gospel teaches that our Lord Himself gave to understand, when He said,
“My Father loves Me; and I have told you this because you love Me.”
Matt. 22:37. The Son, says the Gospel, is love itself: He is not merely
love, but He is love, as the Father loved Him.

The two following sections of the Gospel of Matthew deal with the
experience of faith in God’s goodness to men. The second chapter has
been rightly translated by the “New Testament Commentary” by Thomas M.
Fairbank and William F. Conk

prediction.line:
The first chapter of the Gospel of Matthew contains an allegory on the
love of the Son to his Father, the greatest of all mysteries, which the
Gospel teaches that our Lord Himself gave to understand, when He said,
“My Father loves Me; and I have told you this because you love Me.”
Matt. 22:37. The Son, says the Gospel, is love itself: He is not merely
love, but He is love, as the Father loved Him.

The two following sections of the Gospel of Matthew deal with the
experience of faith in God’s goodness to men. The second chapter has
been rightly translated by the “New Testament Commentary” by Thomas M.
Fairbank and William F. Conk

I. B. The history of this work is, it is believed, the most accurate known at the present time concerning the Christian and the Jewish religious movements in the ancient world. The author has gathered a great deal of material from several sources and has also collected a number of facts concerning the development of the religions which have not hitherto been published. He has written his work in such a way that it makes the most use of the existing information about the religious life of the ancients, but also takes advantage of the information about the religious life that may have existed in other times which have never been investigated. His work is so full of facts that a complete and careful study of it would take many pages.

ocr.sentence: 34 Zephyrum dicit in plantas nutricium exercere.
ocr.region: πνεύματος ἐπιρροῆῇ ἀέρα ὑγρὸν ἕλκοντες ὥσπερ νήπιοι παῖδες. Pliny H. M. 18. 34 Zephyrum dicit in plantas nutricium exercere. Lucian Bis accus. § 1 rods ἀνέ- μους purovpyowras. We might add Catull. 62. 39 ut flos.. | Quem mulcent aurae, firmat sol, educat imber.—va ψυχὴν ἀτάλλων. Cp. Tr. 144 τὸ γὰρ νεάζον ἐν τοιοῖσδε βόσκεται| χώροισιν αὐ- τοῦ εἰς. (n.). The word ἀτάλλω (which in Il. 13. 27 means ‘to gambol’) bears the sense of ‘cherishing’ in Hom. epigr. 4. 2 νήπιον αἰδοίης ἐπὶ γούνασι μητρὸς ἀτάλλων, and Pind. fr. 214 γλυκεῖά ol καρδίαν drd\oira... | ἐλπίς. The Homeric form in this sense is ἀτιτάλλω, Od. 18. 323 παῖδα ds ἀτίταλλε. The word drdMw may have been sug- gested to Sophocles by a trait in the scene between Hector and Andromachè: II. 6. 400 παῖδ’ ἐπὶ κόλπῳ ἔχουσ’ ἀταλά- φρονα, νήπιον atrws. χαρμονήν might be acc. in appos. with ψυχὴν only; but is better taken as acc. in agpos. with the whole sentence (see on El 130 ἤκετ’ ἐμῶν καμάτων wapa- utio).—The conjecture χαρμονή is no gain. 880 It is strange that exception should have been taken to the parenthetic οἶδα, which is not rare; cp. 938, O. C. 1615, El. 334. — obros.. p: cp. 83, 421.

We might add Catull. 62. 39 ut flos.. | Quem mulcent aurae, firmat sol, educat imber.— νέαν ψυχὴν ἀτάλλων. Cp. Tr. 144 τὸ γὰρ νεάζον ἐν τοιοῖσδε βόσκεται χώροισιν αὐ- τοῦ etc. (n.). The Homeric form in this sense is ἀτιτάλλω, Od. 18. 323 παῖδα δὲ ὧς ἀτίταλλε. The word ἀτάλλω (which in Il. 13. 27 means ‘to gambol’) bears the sense of ‘cherishing’ in Hom. epigr. 4. 2 νήπιον αἰδοίης ἐπὶ γούνασι μητρὸς ἀτάλλων, and Pind. fr. 214 γλυκεῖά ol καρδίαν drd\oira... | ἐλπίς. The Homeric form in this sense is ἀτιτάλλω, Od. 18. 323 παῖδα ds ἀτίταλλε. The word drdMw may have been sug- gested to Sophocles by a trait in the scene between Hector and Andromachè: II. 6. 400 παῖδ’ ἐπὶ κόλπῳ ἔχουσ’ ἀταλά- φρονα, νήπιον atrws. χαρμονήν might be acc. in appos. with ψυχὴν only; but is better taken as acc. in agpos. with the whole sentence (see on El 130 ἤκετ’ ἐμῶν καμάτων wapa- utio).—The conjecture χαρμονή is no gain. 880 It is strange that exception should have been taken to the parenthetic οἶδα, which is not rare; cp. 938, O. C. 1615, El. 334. — obros.. p: cp. 83, 421.

We might add Catull. 62. 39 ut flos.. | Quem mulcent aurae, firmat sol, educat imber.—va ψυχὴν ἀτάλλων. Cp. Tr. 144 τὸ γὰρ νεάζον ἐν τοιοῖσδε βόσκεται| χώροισιν αὐ- τοῦ εἰς. (n.). The word ἀτάλλω (which in Il. 13. 27 means ‘to gambol’) bears the sense of ‘cherishing’ in Hom. epigr. 4. 2 νήπιον αἰδοίης ἐπὶ γούνασι μητρὸς ἀτάλλων, and Pind. fr. 214 γλυκεῖά ol καρδίαν drd\oira... | ἐλπίς. The Homeric form in this sense is ἀτιτάλλω, Od. 18. 323 παῖδα ds ἀτίταλλε. The word drdMw may have been sug- gested to Sophocles by a trait in the scene between Hector and Andromachè: II. 6. 400 παῖδ’ ἐπὶ κόλπῳ ἔχουσ’ ἀταλά φρονα, νήπιον atrws. χαρμονήν might be acc. in appos. with ψυχὴν only; but is better taken as acc. in agpos. with the whole sentence (see on El 130 ἤκετ’ ἐμῶν καμάτων wapa- utio).—The conjecture χαρμονή is no gain. 880 It is strange that exception should have been taken to the parenthetic οἶδα, which is not rare; cp. 938, O. C. 1615, El. 334. — obros.. p: cp. 83, 421.

QUESTION 1
The word ἀτάλλω (which in Il. 13. 27 means ‘to gambol’) bears the sense of ‘cherishing’ in Hom. epigr. 4. 2. Did you think that it might be a derivation from the Greek ἐάλκω, which in the sense of ‘to cherish’ has been found in Hesiod (Theog. 12. 14, 13. 30, 14. 34, 15. 19), in Homeric poems (Od. 10. 323, 12. 826), in the Latin epic Ovid’s Encolpion (O. 12. 844), in the Latin tragedians Ovid, Plautus

Tro.



I. The Trojan horse. III. The flight.
I. Introduction.
1.1. The Trojan Horse. The Trojan Horse in the classical literature consists of a passage in which the hero (usually a prince) is taken captive in a battle and his wife and children are sold into slavery on the island of Troy. The passage is usually short, usually less than two pages, and is often accompanied by a short story to describe the captivity and the escape. This story is called a 'drama', and it may be written in a modern or ancient language.
1.2. Historical background. The Trojan Horse is sometimes called a 'legend' or a 'drama

τροφῆς doxvov: any adj. compounded with a privativum can take a genitive.

I. The Trojan horse. III. The flight.
I. Introduction.
1.1. The Trojan Horse. The Trojan Horse in the classical literature consists of a passage in which the hero (usually a prince) is taken captive in a battle and his wife and children are sold into slavery on the island of Troy. The passage is usually short, usually less than two pages, and is often accompanied by a short story to describe the captivity and the escape. This story is called a 'drama', and it may be written in a modern or ancient language.

Lucret.

A work of pure philosophy, containing, in one book, a concise exposition of the doctrine of the immortality of the soul, in which no effort is made to preserve, in language, the exact sense of any passages, but only a few selected, with a view to render the ideas more clear and easily understood.



CORRECTED TEXT:
Lucret.

A work of pure philosophy, containing, in one book, a concise exposition of the doctrine of the immortality of the soul, in which no effort is made to preserve, in language, the exact sense of any passages, but only a few selected, with a view to render the ideas more clear and easily understood.</s>

Lucret.

A work of pure philosophy, containing, in one book, a concise exposition of the doctrine of the immortality of the soul, in which no effort is made to preserve, in language, the exact sense of any passages, but only a few selected, with a view to render the ideas more clear and easily understood.

Lucret.

A work of pure philosophy, containing, in one book, a concise exposition of the doctrine of the immortality of the soul, in which no effort is made to preserve, in language, the exact sense of any passages, but only a few selected, with a view to render the ideas more clear and easily understood.</s>

The book of Ecclesiastes. It was said that a certain sage had once seen an eagle fall and in a dream took a piece of the wing off the eagle's back. He then taught the wise to do the same. In the same way we find the wonderful truth that the one and only Christ has, as it were, given himself to receive the shame of sin, to become a servant of God, in order that every creature who loves him may be able to be united to him through faith, and all those who are holy may share in his grace and virtue. To be the son of God is to love and to serve Him, to die to sin and to receive the resurrection to life eternal.
The only way that this truth can be known is by means of faith, a word that has many meanings in different languages. The word itself has a positive meaning (which expresses the willingness to believe) and it can have a negative meaning (which expresses the impossibility of believing), and can express a general conviction, or a conviction that is specific to a subject. In the following, we will use the positive meaning of faith, which is the expression of the certainty of something to be believed or to be true, that can be derived from direct experience or from previous experience. prediction.line:
In the sixth century, the Christian church of Alexandria had a peculiar dispute with the Jews regarding the concept of the existence of an eternal God. The Christian fathers, mostly the Fathers of Alexandria, rejected the teaching of the Jews concerning God, arguing that the Messiah of the Old Testament had never been incarnate and that the Bible was therefore incomplete. The dispute became bitter, and eventually culminated in the so-called Jerusalem council in AD 325, at which the Roman emperor Constantine formally condemned Judaism and Christianity as "non-Christian" religions. The council, which consisted mainly of Jews, declared the Jews to be a people "from the east" and the Christians of Alexandria to be "a people from the west."

Traditional historical linguistics is based on textual linguistic analysis of manuscripts. However, this approach can be challenging for people with limited or no linguistic expertise, as they often have to interpret large amounts of texts written in non-standard languages. Here, the traditional approach is complemented by automatic transcription and OCR, a process that converts raw text into a sequence of digital features (e.g. digits, letters, characters, symbols, etc.) suitable for statistical analysis. While the process of automatic transcription and OCR is widely used today for the analysis of large amounts of textual material, automatic transcription of texts with a large variety of orthographic and linguistic variants can be a daunting task.

Odysseus was angry when his father Agamemnon left him. Odysseus returned to his house with an eagle in his hand, where he soon got angry with his best friend Aias, because he had no news about the King of the Eldians who was with him at that time. He took care of the eagle so as to save his skin from being broken. He was glad to hear that Aias was safe. Vgl. 78 HF.

Odysseus was angry when his father Agamemnon left him. Odysseus returned to his house with an eagle in his hand, where he soon got angry with his best friend Aias, because he had no news about the King of the Eldians who was with him at that time. He took care of the eagle so as to save his skin from being broken. He was glad to hear that Aias was safe. Vgl. 78 HF.

ocr.line: möchte. εὔρινος (Nebenform zu εὔρις) bei βάσις worin τὸ εὕρινον ſich
ocr.region: möchte. εὔρινος (Nebenform zu εὔρις) bei βάσις worin τὸ edowor ſich zu erkennen gibt, wie oft Epitheta von der Perſon auf die Handlung übertragen werden. Die lakoniſchen Hunde, welche bei der Jagd im Taygetos dienten, werden ſchon von Pindar Fragm. 83 als treffliche Spürhunde ge- rühmt. 10. Das Epitheton ξιφοκτόνους vertritt die Stelle von aluarı (στάζων). 13. örov.. μάθῃς d. 1. ſage mir, was du erfahren willſt; ich kann dir Auskunft geben. 14. Bei Sophokles kommt nur die Form 496"a vor, bei Äſchylo8 auch die alte, feierliche Form Ἀθηναία. 15. ds iſt cauſal. Odyſſeus gibt an, warum er Athena ſofort erkannt habe. εὐμαθές iſt be- tont als Gegenſaß zu ἄποπτος (wenn ich dich auch nicht deutlich ſehe, er- kenne ich doch deutlich deine Stimme“). — ἐάν . 7/5, immer wie jetzt. — ἄποπτος („in der Ferne geſehen“) entſpricht der Illuſion, für welche Athena hoch in den Wolken ſchwebt. — 6uos ſchließt ſich dem Saße mit za: εἰ (ar) oder dem entſprechenden Participinm an. Kr. II 8 56, 13, 2. 16. Errao- πάζω poeri gibt kräftig die Metapher, die in ovrinu niht mehr gefühlt wird, und bezeichnet die unmittelbare, raſche Auffaſſung. 17. Die er- ſchütternde und das Herz erbeben machende Stimme der Göttin wird ver- glichen mit der διάτορος Τυρσηνικὴ σάλπιγξ, wie die Drommete, als deren Erfinder die Tyrrhener (Etrusker) galten, Äſch. Eum. 570 wegen ihres ſcharfen, ſchmetternden Tons genannt wird. — ὡς (φώνημα) κώδωνος (κώ- dc» das Schalloch der Drommete iſt hier der bezeichnende Teil; die nähere Beſtimmung liegt in Τυρσηνικῆς). Vgl. Hom. € 219. 18f. Mit zai vor, welches zu ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυσμενεῖ P. κυκλοῦντα gehört, beſtätigt Odyſſeus die Übereinſtimmung mit ſeinem ſonſtigen Thun (2). Nach dem Sinne des Odyſſeus ſoll Alavıı 7. σ. eine überraſchende Erklärung zu ἀνδοὶ δυσ- μενεῖ fein. — σακεσφόρος heißt Aias als Träger des oazos ἑπταβόειον (Hom. H 219 Αἴας δ’ ἐγγύθεν ἦλθε φέρων σάκος ἠύτε πύργον). Vgl. 576.

Bei Sophokles kommt nur die Form Ἀθάνα vor, bei Äſchylos auch die alte, feierliche Form Ἀθηναία. 15. ὡς iſt cauſal. Odyſſeus gibt an, warum er Athena ſofort erkannt habe. εὐμαθές iſt be⸗ tont als Gegenſatz zu ἄποπτος (wenn ich dich auch nicht deutlich ſehe, er⸗ kenne ich doch deutlich deine Stimme"). - ἐάν . . ᾖς, immer wie jetzt.- ἄποπτος („in der Ferne geſehen") entſpricht der Illuſion, für welche Athena hoch in den Wolken ſchwebt. - ὅμως ſchließt ſich dem Satze mit καὶ εἰ (ἐάν) oder dem entſprechenden Participium an. Kr. II § 56, 13, 2. 16. ξυναρ- πάζω φρενί gibt kräftig die Metapher, die in συνίημι nicht mehr gefühlt wird, und bezeichnet die unmittelbare, raſche Auffaſſung. 17. Vgl. Hom. Σ 219. 18 f. Mit καὶ νῦν . welches zu ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυσμενεῖ β. κυκλοῦντα gehört, bestätigt Odyſſeus die Übereinſtimmung mit ſeinem ſonſtigen Thun (2). Nach dem Sinne des Odyſſeus ſoll Αἴαντι τ. σ. eine überraſchende Erklärung zu ἀνδρὶ δυσ- μενεῖ ſein. - σακεσφόρος heißt Aias als Träger des σάκος ἑπταβόειον (Hom. H 219 Αἴας δ’ ἐγγύθεν ἦλθε φέρων σάκος ἠύτε πύργον). Vgl. 576.

Das Epitheton ξιφοκτόνους vertritt die Stelle von aluarı (στάζων). 13. örov.. μάθῃς d. 1. ſage mir, was du erfahren willſt; ich kann dir Auskunft geben. 14. Bei Sophokles kommt nur die Form 496"a vor, bei Äſchylo8 auch die alte, feierliche Form Ἀθηναία. 15. ds iſt cauſal. Odyſſeus gibt an, warum er Athena ſofort erkannt habe. εὐμαθές iſt be- tont als Gegenſaß zu ἄποπτος (wenn ich dich auch nicht deutlich ſehe, er- kenne ich doch deutlich deine Stimme“). — ἐάν . 7/5, immer wie jetzt. — ἄποπτος („in der Ferne geſehen“) entſpricht der Illuſion, für welche Athena hoch in den Wolken ſchwebt. — 6uos ſchließt ſich dem Saße mit za: εἰ (ar) oder dem entſprechenden Participinm an. Kr. II 8 56, 13, 2. 16. Errao- πάζω poeri gibt kräftig die Metapher, die in ovrinu niht mehr gefühlt wird, und bezeichnet die unmittelbare, raſche Auffaſſung. 17. Die er- ſchütternde und das Herz erbeben machende Stimme der Göttin wird ver- glichen mit der διάτορος Τυρσηνικὴ σάλπιγξ, wie die Drommete, als deren Erfinder die Tyrrhener (Etrusker) galten, Äſch. Eum. 570 wegen ihres ſcharfen, ſchmetternden Tons genannt wird. — ὡς (φώνημα) κώδωνος (κώ- dc» das Schalloch der Drommete iſt hier der bezeichnende Teil; die nähere Beſtimmung liegt in Τυρσηνικῆς). Vgl. Hom. € 219. 18f. Mit zai vor, welches zu ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυσμενεῖ P. κυκλοῦντα gehört, beſtätigt Odyſſeus die Übereinſtimmung mit ſeinem ſonſtigen Thun (2). Nach dem Sinne des Odyſſeus ſoll Alavıı 7. σ. eine überraſchende Erklärung zu ἀνδοὶ δυσ- μενεῖ fein. — σακεσφόρος heißt Aias als Träger des oazos ἑπταβόειον (Hom. H 219 Αἴας δ’ ἐγγύθεν ἦλθε φέρων σάκος ἠύτε πύργον). Vgl. 576.

groundtruth.region: möchte. εὔρινος (Nebenform zu εὔρις) bei βάσις worin τὸ εὕρινον ſich zu erkennen gibt, wie oft Epitheta von der Perſon auf die Handlung übertragen werden. Die lakoniſchen Hunde, welche bei der Jagd im Taygetos dienten, werden ſchon von Pindar Fragm. 83 als treffliche Spürhunde ge⸗ rühmt. 10. Das Epitheton ξιφοκτόνους vertritt die Stelle von αἵματι (στάζων). 13. ὅτου.. μάθῃς d. i. ſage mir, was du erfahren willſt: ich kann dir Auskunft geben. 14. Bei Sophokles kommt nur die Form Ἀθάνα vor, bei Äſchylos auch die alte, feierliche Form Ἀθηναία. 15. ὡς iſt cauſal. Odyſſeus gibt an, warum er Athena ſofort erkannt habe. εὐμαθές iſt be⸗ tont als Gegenſatz zu ἄποπτος (wenn ich dich auch nicht deutlich ſehe, er⸗ kenne ich doch deutlich deine Stimme"). - ἐάν . . ᾖς, immer wie jetzt.- ἄποπτος („in der Ferne geſehen") entſpricht der Illuſion, für welche Athena hoch in den Wolken ſchwebt. - ὅμως ſchließt ſich dem Satze mit καὶ εἰ (ἐάν) oder dem entſprechenden Participium an. Kr. II § 56, 13, 2. 16. ξυναρ- πάζω φρενί gibt kräftig die Metapher, die in συνίημι nicht mehr gefühlt wird, und bezeichnet die unmittelbare, raſche Auffaſſung. 17. Die er⸗ ſchütternde und das Herz erbeben machende Stimme der Göttin wird ver⸗ glichen mit der διάτορος Τυρσηνικὴ σάλπιγξ, wie die Drommete, als deren Erfinder die Tyrrhener (Etrusker) galten, Äſch. Eum. 570 wegen ihres ſcharfen, ſchmetternden Tons genannt wird. - ὡς (φώνημα) κώδωνος (κώ- δων das Schalloch der Drommete iſt hier der bezeichnende Teil; die nähere Beſtimmung liegt in Τυρσηνικῆς). Vgl. Hom. Σ 219. 18 f. Mit καὶ νῦν . welches zu ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυσμενεῖ β. κυκλοῦντα gehört, bestätigt Odyſſeus die Übereinſtimmung mit ſeinem ſonſtigen Thun (2). Nach dem Sinne des Odyſſeus ſoll Αἴαντι τ. σ. eine überraſchende Erklärung zu ἀνδρὶ δυσ- μενεῖ ſein. - σακεσφόρος heißt Aias als Träger des σάκος ἑπταβόειον (Hom. H 219 Αἴας δ’ ἐγγύθεν ἦλθε φέρων σάκος ἠύτε πύργον). Vgl. 576.

Die er⸗ ſchütternde und das Herz erbeben machende Stimme der Göttin wird ver⸗ glichen mit der διάτορος Τυρσηνικὴ σάλπιγξ, wie die Drommete, als deren Erfinder die Tyrrhener (Etrusker) galten, Äſch. Eum. 570 wegen ihres ſcharfen, ſchmetternden Tons genannt wird. - ὡς (φώνημα) κώδωνος (κώ- δων das Schalloch der Drommete iſt hier der bezeichnende Teil; die nähere Beſtimmung liegt in Τυρσηνικῆς). Vgl. Hom. Σ 219. 18 f. Mit καὶ νῦν . welches zu ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυσμενεῖ β. κυκλοῦντα gehört, bestätigt Odyſſeus die Übereinſtimmung mit ſeinem ſonſtigen Thun (2). Nach dem Sinne des Odyſſeus ſoll Αἴαντι τ. σ. eine überraſchende Erklärung zu ἀνδρὶ δυσ- μενεῖ ſein. - σακεσφόρος heißt Aias als Träger des σάκος ἑπταβόειον (Hom. H 219 Αἴας δ’ ἐγγύθεν ἦλθε φέρων σάκος ἠύτε πύργον). Vgl. 576.

prediction.line: the law regarding the fishery was issued by Emperor Diocletian in the year AD 283.</s>
prediction.sentence:
576.1
Hic tenet, etiam in hoc temporis non sunt, sed si tamen fuerit invenire, cum vixit, ita ut ex omnibus gentes fuerint, et in aliis in eorum prædicationibus se repugnant. Et, cum dicunt, Quare non sunt non est? Ex hoc dicit omnes, neque ipsi non sunt. Quia autem, si sunt non sunt, nisi eorum potestate non est. Sic autem est non sunt, ut si non sunt, ut non sunt.
576.2

ocr.line: pareat. 1076. πρόβλημα δ. i. dem nicht etwas, das er fürchtet und
ocr.region: pareat. 1076. πρόβλημα ». i. dem nicht etwas, das er fürchtet und ſcheut, vor Augen ſteht. — Der Schol. führt einen Spruch des Epicharm an: Evda 6205, Evradda καὶ alöws. Die Furcht galt den Griechen als Haltpunkt jeder geſellſchaftlichen Ordnung. 1077. γεννήσῃ hat Sopho⸗ kles nach Analogie von φύειν (πώγωνα, πτερά, ὀδόντας) gebraut. — μέγα proleptiſches Prädikat wie δεινόν 1124. 1080. Vgl. Hom. E 351 αἰδομένων ἀνδρῶν πλέονες σόοι ἠὲ πέφανται, Ant.675f. 1081f. 670v .. ταύτην τὴν πόλιν wie Phil. 456 ὅπου . . τούτους τοὺς ἄνδρας. — δρᾶν ἃ βούλεται (willkürlich ſchalten und walten): Subjekt iſt der bei ὑβρίζειν δρᾶν re vorſchwebende allgemeine Begriff (ris) Kr. 1 8 64, 4,5. — zao07: zu 496. 1083. Es findet fih 85 ovoim» (πνευμάτων) Dew, πλεῖν, φέρεσθαι wie ἐξ οὐρίας πλεῖν, κομίζεσθαι (Beiſpiele bei Lobe). In demſelben Sinne ſteht οὔρια θεῖν (mit günſtigem Winde fahren). — πεσεῖν das Futurum wird Durch χρόνῳ ποτὲ („früher oder ſpäter“) vertreten. 1084. xai δέος, auch Furcht, nicht bloß Willkür. — καίριον, zu rechter Zeit ſich ein- ſtellend, heilſam. — Vgl. Aſch. Eum. 920 ἔσθ’ ὅπου To δεινὸν εὖ . . ξυμφέρει σωφρονεῖν ὑπὸ oreveı. 1085 f. Über ἥδεσθαί τι Kr. 1846, 6,9, Cu. 8 153, 3, Kr. 8 83, Ku. 825, 3. — Der Endreim hebt das Gleich⸗ mäßige des Inhalts. 1090. Vgl. Eur. Phön. 1657 Antigone: ἐγώ oe Vapo, x0V ἀπεννέπῃ πόλις. Kreon: σαυτὴν do’ ἐγγὺς τῷδε συνθάψεις νεκρῷ.
groundtruth.line: pareat. 1076. πρόβλημα ». i. dem nicht etwas, das er fürchtet und
groundtruth.region: pareat. 1076. πρόβλημα δ. i. dem nicht etwas, das er fürchtet und ſcheut, vor Augen ſteht.- Der Schol. führt einen Spruch des Epicharm an: ἔνθα δέος, ἐνταῦθα καὶ αἰδώς. Die Furcht galt den Griechen als Haltpunkt jeder geſellſchaftlichen Ordnung. 1077. γεννήσῃ hat Sopho⸗ kles nach Analogie von φύειν (πώγωνα, πτερά, ὀδόντας) gebraucht. - μέγα proleptiſches Prädikat wie δεινόν 1124. 1080. Vgl. Hom. E 351 αἰδομένων ἀνδρῶν πλέονες σόοι ἠὲ πέφανται, Ant. 675 f. 1081 f, ὅπου . . ταύτην τὴν πόλιν wie Phil. 456 ὅπου . . τούτους τοὺς ἄνδρας. - δρᾶν ἃ βούλεται (willkürlich ſchalten und walten): Subjekt iſt der bei ὑβρίζειν δρᾶν τε vorſchwebende allgemeine Begriff (τίς) Kr. I § 61, 4, 5. - παρῇ: zu 496. 1083. Es findet ſich ἐξ οὐρίων (πνευμάτων) θεῖν, πλεῖν, φέρεσθαι wie ἐξ οὐρίας πλεῖν, κομίζεσθαι (Beiſpiele bei Lobeck). In demſelben Sinne ſteht οὔρια θεῖν (mit günſtigem Winde fahren). - πεσεῖν: das Futurum wird durch χρόνῳ ποτὲ („früher oder ſpäter") vertreten. 1084. καὶ δέος, auch Furcht, nicht bloß Willkür. - καίριον, zu rechter Zeit ſich ein⸗ ſtellend, heilſam. - Vgl. Aſch. Eum. 520 ἔσθ’ ὅπου τὸ δεινὸν εὖ . . ξυμφέρει σωφρονεῖν ὑπὸ στένει. 1085 f. Über ἥδεσθαί τι Kr. I § 46, 6, 9, Cu. § 153, 3, Kr. § 83, Ku. § 25, 3. - Der Endreim hebt das Gleich⸗ mäßige des Inhalts. 1090. Vgl. Eur. Phön. 1657 Antigone: ἐγώ σφε θάψω, κἂν ἀπεννέπῃ πόλις. Kreon: σαυτὴν ἄρ’ ἐγγὺς τῷδε συνθάψεις νεκρῷ.

ἔργου οὐκ ἔργου δέ οὐχ ἔργου
The passage has the form οὐκ ἔργου δέ οὐχ ἔργου. The OCR has transcribed οὐκ ἔργου δέ οὐχ ἔργου. The text should read οὐκ ἔργου δὲ οὐχ ἔργου ("not something", "that he forecasts and").</s>

prediction.sentence:
1080.


ABBREVIATIONS

Introduction:

A) Greek and Latin Script
The Latin and Greek letters have a different shape, the Greek letters being more elongated and the Latin letters more rounded, like the Greek alphabet in the old testament. But this is not true for the spelling. So we do not have a real difference in form but only in spelling.
B) Old and New Testament
The Old Testament was written in ancient Greek and the New Testament in Latin. The same spelling is used for both. The difference is mainly due to the writing style of the translator. For example, the word "Hosanna" is written as (HoSAnna) instead of (HoSANNa).
C

ocr.region: pareat. 1076. πρόβλημα ». i. dem nicht etwas, das er fürchtet und ſcheut, vor Augen ſteht. — Der Schol. führt einen Spruch des Epicharm an: Evda 6205, Evradda καὶ alöws. E 351 αἰδομένων ἀνδρῶν πλέονες σόοι ἠὲ πέφανται, Ant.675f. 1081f. 670v .. ταύτην τὴν πόλιν wie Phil. 456 ὅπου . . τούτους τοὺς ἄνδρας. — δρᾶν ἃ βούλεται (willkürlich ſchalten und walten): Subjekt iſt der bei ὑβρίζειν δρᾶν re vorſchwebende allgemeine Begriff (ris) Kr. 1 8 64, 4,5. — zao07: zu 496. 1083. In demſelben Sinne ſteht οὔρια θεῖν (mit günſtigem Winde fahren). — πεσεῖν das Futurum wird Durch χρόνῳ ποτὲ („früher oder ſpäter“) vertreten. 1084. xai δέος, auch Furcht, nicht bloß Willkür. — καίριον, zu rechter Zeit ſich ein- ſtellend, heilſam. — Vgl. Aſch. Eum. 920 ἔσθ’ ὅπου To δεινὸν εὖ . . ξυμφέρει σωφρονεῖν ὑπὸ oreveı. 1085 f. Über ἥδεσθαί τι Kr. 1846, 6,9, Cu. 8 153, 3, Kr. 8 83, Ku. 825, 3. — Der Endreim hebt das Gleich⸗ mäßige des Inhalts. 1090. Vgl. Eur. Phön. 1657 Antigone: ἐγώ oe Vapo, x0V ἀπεννέπῃ πόλις. groundtruth.region: pareat. 1076. πρόβλημα δ. i. dem nicht etwas, das er fürchtet und ſcheut, vor Augen ſteht.- Der Schol. führt einen Spruch des Epicharm an: ἔνθα δέος, ἐνταῦθα καὶ αἰδώς. Die Furcht galt den Griechen als Haltpunkt jeder geſellſchaftlichen Ordnung. 1077. γεννήσῃ hat Sopho⸗ kles nach Analogie von φύειν (πώγωνα, πτερά, ὀδόντας) gebraucht. - μέγα proleptiſches Prädikat wie δεινόν 1124. 1080. Vgl. Hom. E 351 αἰδομένων ἀνδρῶν πλέονες σόοι ἠὲ πέφανται, Ant. 675 f. 1081 f, ὅπου . . ταύτην τὴν πόλιν wie Phil. 456 ὅπου . . τούτους τοὺς ἄνδρας. - δρᾶν ἃ βούλεται (willkürlich ſchalten und walten): Subjekt iſt der bei ὑβρίζειν δρᾶν τε vorſchwebende allgemeine Begriff (τίς) Kr. I § 61, 4, 5. - παρῇ: zu 496. 1083. Es findet ſich ἐξ οὐρίων (πνευμάτων) θεῖν, πλεῖν, φέρεσθαι wie ἐξ οὐρίας πλεῖν, κομίζεσθαι (Beiſpiele bei Lobeck). ocr.line: pareat. 1076. πρόβλημα δ. i. dem nicht etwas, das er fürchtet und
ocr.region: pareat. 1076. πρόβλημα ». i. dem nicht etwas, das er fürchtet und ſcheut, vor Augen ſteht. — Der Schol. führt einen Spruch des Epicharm an: Evda 6205, Evradda καὶ alöws. Die Furcht galt den Griechen als Haltpunkt jeder geſellſchaftlichen Ordnung. 1077. γεννήσῃ hat Sopho⸗ kles nach Analogie von φύειν (πώγωνα, πτερά, ὀδόντας) gebraut. — μέγα proleptiſches Prädikat wie δεινόν 1124. 1080. Vgl. Hom. E 351 αἰδομένων ἀνδρῶν πλέονες σόοι ἠὲ πέφανται, Ant.675f. 1081f. 670v .. ταύτην τὴν πόλιν wie Phil. 456 ὅπου . . τούτους τοὺς ἄνδρας. — δρᾶν ἃ βούλεται (willkürlich ſchalten und walten): Subjekt iſt der bei ὑβρίζειν δρᾶν re vorſchwebende allgemeine Begriff (ris) Kr. 1 8 64, 4,5. — zao07: zu 496. 1083. Es findet fih 85 ovoim» (πνευμάτων) Dew, πλεῖν, φέρεσθαι wie ἐξ οὐρίας πλεῖν, κομίζεσθαι (Beiſpiele bei Lobe). In demſelben Sinne ſteht οὔρια θεῖν (mit günſtigem Winde fahren). — πεσεῖν das Futurum wird Durch χρόνῳ ποτὲ („früher oder ſpäter“) vertreten. 1084. xai δέος, auch Furcht, nicht bloß Willkür. — καίριον, zu rechter Zeit ſich ein- ſtellend, heilſam. — Vgl. Aſch. Eum. 920 ἔσθ’ ὅπου To δεινὸν εὖ . . ξυμφέρει σωφρονεῖν ὑπὸ oreveı. 1085 f. Über ἥδεσθαί τι Kr. 1846, 6,9, Cu. 8 153, 3, Kr. 8 83, Ku. 825, 3. — Der Endreim hebt das Gleich⸗ mäßige des Inhalts. 1090. Vgl. Eur. Phön. 1657 Antigone: ἐγώ oe Vapo, x0V ἀπεννέπῃ πόλις. Kreon: σαυτὴν do’ ἐγγὺς τῷδε συνθάψεις νεκρῷ.
groundtruth.line: pareat. 1076. πρόβλημα ». i. dem nicht etwas, das er fürchtet und
groundtruth.region: pareat. 1076. πρόβλημα δ. i. dem nicht etwas, das er fürchtet und ſcheut, vor Augen ſteht.- Der Schol. führt einen Spruch des Epicharm an: ἔνθα δέος, ἐνταῦθα καὶ αἰδώς. Die Furcht galt den Griechen als Haltpunkt jeder geſellſchaftlichen Ordnung. 1077. γεννήσῃ hat Sopho⸗ kles nach Analogie von φύειν (πώγωνα, πτερά, ὀδόντας) gebraucht. - μέγα proleptiſches Prädikat wie δεινόν 1124. 1080. Vgl. Hom. E 351 αἰδομένων ἀνδρῶν πλέονες σόοι ἠὲ πέφανται, Ant. 675 f. 1081 f, ὅπου . . ταύτην τὴν πόλιν wie Phil. 456 ὅπου . . τούτους τοὺς ἄνδρας. - δρᾶν ἃ βούλεται (willkürlich ſchalten und walten): Subjekt iſt der bei ὑβρίζειν δρᾶν τε vorſchwebende allgemeine Begriff (τίς) Kr. I § 61, 4, 5. - παρῇ: zu 496. 1083. Es findet ſich ἐξ οὐρίων (πνευμάτων) θεῖν, πλεῖν, φέρεσθαι wie ἐξ οὐρίας πλεῖν, κομίζεσθαι (Beiſpiele bei Lobeck). In demſelben Sinne ſteht οὔρια θεῖν (mit günſtigem Winde fahren). - πεσεῖν: das Futurum wird durch χρόνῳ ποτὲ („früher oder ſpäter") vertreten. 1084. καὶ δέος, auch Furcht, nicht bloß Willkür. - καίριον, zu rechter Zeit ſich ein⸗ ſtellend, heilſam. - Vgl. Aſch. Eum. 520 ἔσθ’ ὅπου τὸ δεινὸν εὖ . . ξυμφέρει σωφρονεῖν ὑπὸ στένει. 1085 f. Über ἥδεσθαί τι Kr. I § 46, 6, 9, Cu. § 153, 3, Kr. § 83, Ku. § 25, 3. - Der Endreim hebt das Gleich⸗ mäßige des Inhalts. 1090. Vgl. Eur. Phön. 1657 Antigone: ἐγώ σφε θάψω, κἂν ἀπεννέπῃ πόλις. Kreon: σαυτὴν ἄρ’ ἐγγὺς τῷδε συνθάψεις νεκρῷ.

prediction.sentence:
1080.


ABBREVIATIONS

Introduction:

A) Greek and Latin Script
The Latin and Greek letters have a different shape, the Greek letters being more elongated and the Latin letters more rounded, like the Greek alphabet in the old testament. But this is not true for the spelling. So we do not have a real difference in form but only in spelling.
B) Old and New Testament
The Old Testament was written in ancient Greek and the New Testament in Latin. The same spelling is used for both. The difference is mainly due to the writing style of the translator. For example, the word "Hosanna" is written as (HoSAnna) instead of (HoSANNa).

In demſelben Sinne ſteht οὔρια θεῖν (mit günſtigem Winde fahren). — πεσεῖν das Futurum wird Durch χρόνῳ ποτὲ („früher oder ſpäter“) vertreten. 1084. xai δέος, auch Furcht, nicht bloß Willkür. — καίριον, zu rechter Zeit ſich ein- ſtellend, heilſam. — Vgl. Über ἥδεσθαί τι Kr. 1846, 6,9, Cu. 8 153, 3, Kr. 8 83, Ku. 825, 3. — Der Endreim hebt das Gleich⸗ mäßige des Inhalts. 1090. Vgl. Eur. Phön. 1657 Antigone: ἐγώ oe Vapo, x0V ἀπεννέπῃ πόλις.
